abstracts.cdata!:
The implementation of the project was
            rated as partial and the outcome unsatisfactory. The key
            lessons learned include: 1) Government commitment is
            important. The government needs to build confidence through
            steady and consistent implementation of reforms. There is a
            perception that over the past decades, Kenya undertook
            reforms in fits and starts. This intermittent approach to
            reform has undermined confidence among aid sources and
            business circles about government commitment. Staff turnover
            was cited as a factor affecting commitment to
            implementation. 2) A coherent policy design is important.
            Given that containing the growth of the government wage bill
            was very critical for consolidating fiscal and financial
            stability, as well as improving the management of public
            resources and redirecting support to priority non-wage
            activities the social sectors, the design of the reform
            program could have been more effective in capturing the main
            pressures points on the wage bill. 3) Performance on
            economic governance measures was less than expected, and
            this affected overall policy performance. Key economic
            governance issues, especially combating corruption,
            enhancing transparency in budget allocation, expenditure
            reporting, and enforcing accountability for the use of
            public resources are now at the center of dialogue with the authorities.

5077238.majtheme: Public sector governance,Trade and integration,Financial and private sector development

abstracts.cdata!:
The Structural Adjustment Credit Project
            is based upon the government's Policy Framework Paper
            and related Letter of Development Policy which set out the
            government's medium term strategy. This strategy has as
            objective the reduction in poverty and unemployment through
            an acceleration of economic growth. This is to achieved by:
            1) strengthening monetary and public sector finance
            management and consolidating fiscal discipline; 2)
            accelerating and streamlining reform in the civil service
            and public enterprises and improving the delivery of
            infrastructural services; 3) liberalization of markets; 4)
            addressing the social aspects of development; and 5)
            eliminating corruption. The project will focus on government
            reforms in the areas of public sector management, public
            enterprise and civil service reform in line with the overall
            medium term strategy. Specific reforms supported by the
            project include: 1) improvement in the quality of public
            expenditures through expenditure reallocation; 2)
            enhancement of efficiency of key public enterprises through
            restructuring and divestiture of activities; 3) reduction in
            the size of the public sector through accelerated
            privatization; and 4) reduction in the size of the civil
            service and improvement in efficiency through ministerial
            rationalization. At the macroeconomic level, the project
            will support government efforts to consolidate the fiscal
            position and improve Kenya's external position to
            levels sustainable over the medium term.
